They say that anyone on the planet can be connected to any other person through a chain of six people, which means that no one is a stranger for long.

In drama Six Degrees from the producers of Lost and Alias, six very different New Yorkers go about their lives without realizing the impact they’re having on one another, but a mysterious web of coincidences gradually draws them closer, changing the course of their lives forever.

An ensemble drama about the possibilities of a greater force at work guiding everyone together and connecting the lives of us all.

About Bridget Moynahan

She is an American model and actress. After graduating from Longmeadow High School in 1989, Moynahan pursued a career in modeling. She was signed by a modeling agency, which led her to appear in everything from department store catalogs to gracing the covers of widely known magazines. After doing television commercials, she began taking acting lessons, in order to change occupations.

Moynahan made her television debut in a guest appearance in the comedy series Sex and the City in 1999, where she would later have a recurring role as the character Natasha. The following year, she made her feature film debut in Coyote Ugly. She was then cast in a supporting role in Serendipity (2001). Moynahan has appeared in an eclectic range of films, including the action film The Sum of All Fears (2002), spy thriller The Recruit (2003), the science-fiction movie I, Robot (2004), and the political thriller Lord of War (2005).

Away from film, Moynahan starred in the ABC television series Six Degrees, which premiered in September 2006. The show, however, was not successful, as it was canceled after one season. Since then, she has returned to film, starring in low-budget features. Moynahan has completed work in Elizabeth Allen's Ramona and Beezus scheduled for release in August 2010. Returning to television, Moynahan will star in the CBS drama Blue Bloods.

In her personal life, Moynahan was in a three-year relationship with screenwriter Scott Rosenberg. She was then in a high-profile relationship with NFL quarterback Tom Brady from 2004 to 2006. In February 2007, it was announced that Moynahan was pregnant with Brady's child. On August 22, 2007, she gave birth to a son, John Edward Thomas.

Moynahan was born in Binghamton, New York, the daughter of Irish American parents Mary Bridget (née Moriarty), a former school teacher, and Edward Bradley Moynahan, a scientist and former administrator at the University of Massachusetts at Amherst. She has two brothers, Andy and Sean. When she was seven, her parents moved to Longmeadow, Massachusetts. Moynahan attended Longmeadow High School, where she was active with school athletics, where she captained the girls' soccer, basketball and lacrosse teams. In 1989, she graduated from Longmeadow High School. She admits that during her childhood, she grew up as a tomboy.

Moynahan was in a three-year relationship with screenwriter Scott Rosenberg. Moynahan dated NFL quarterback Tom Brady from 2004 until December 14, 2006. On February 18, 2007, Moynahan's representative confirmed to People that she was more than three months pregnant and that Brady was the father. On August 22, 2007, she gave birth to a baby boy, John Edward Thomas Moynahan, at Saint John's Health Center in Santa Monica. In a July 2008 interview in Harper's Bazaar, Moynahan discussed her willingness to raise her son (nicknamed "Jack") as a single mother. Despite media reports that Moynahan and Brady have an acrimonious relationship, it was revealed that the two have maintained "a civil relationship" since the birth of their son.

Moynahan resides in Pacific Palisades, California. In November 2009, it was announced that Moynahan had signed a deal with Garnier to appear in television and print advertising promoting their Nutrisse hair products.

Bridget Moynahan Biography

Bridget Moynahan is an American actress and model who is best known for her role as Erin Reagan in the police drama Blue Bloods. Following her education, she graduated from Longmeadow High School in Massachusetts in 1989 and began pursuing a career in modeling. In high school, she was captain of the girl’s soccer, basketball, and lacrosse teams.

After graduating from high school, she pursued a modeling career admitting she has never read fashion magazines. She appeared in department-store catalogs and magazines. After doing television commercials, she began taking acting lessons. Most notably, she began her television debut in a guest appearance in the comedy series Sex and the City in 1999. She later had a recurring role in the series as Natasha.

Moynahan moved to New York City at the age of 18, and, a year later, began appearing in magazines such as Vogue and Elle. Her cover highlights include Vogue Paris, Elle, and Glamour. During that time, she began doing soap and shampoo commercials which were in addition to taking acting and art classes. Moynahan studied acting at the Carmichael Patten Studio in New York, and in 1999, made her TV debut.

Moynahan made her feature-film debut in Coyote Ugly (2000). She was also cast in Serendipity and was also featured in films The Sum of All Fears, The Recruit, I, Robert, Lord of War, Prey, Noise, and John Wick: Chapter 2. In addition, she starred in the ABC television series Six Degrees, which premiered in September 2006. She is currently starring as an assistant district attorney in the CBS drama Blue Bloods since September 2010.

Bridget Moynahan Age

How old is Moynahan? Moynahan is 52 years old as of 2023. She was born on April 28, 1971, in Binghamton, New York, United States. In addition, she celebrates her birthday on April 28 every year and her zodiac sign is Taurus.

Bridget Moynahan’s Height

Moynahan stands at an average height of 5 feet 10 inches and weighs 57 kg equivalent to 126 lbs.

Bridget Moynahan Family

Moynahan is the proud daughter of Mary Bridget (mother) and Edward Bradley Moynahan (father). Her mother is an Irish American while her father is a former administrator at the University of Massachusetts Amherst. In addition, she has an older brother, Andy, and a younger brother, Sean. Andy works as a computer programmer while Sean is a potter.

Bridget Moynahan Husband | Son

Moynahan was married to Scott Rosenberg in 2001 but separated in 2003. Later on, in 2004 she got married to Tom Brady but separated in 2006. On August 22, 2007, she gave birth to her son, John Edward Thomas. Most notably, she is currently married to Andrew Frankel. They got married on October 17, 2015, in the Hamptons. Frank is a businessman and has three sons from a previous relationship.

Bridget Moynahan Net Worth

Moynahan has an estimated net worth of $30 Million. Her income is attributed to her successful career as a journalist.

Bridget Moynahan is an actress, writer, mum, and model most popularly known for her role as Assistant District Attorney Erin Reagan in the CBS television police drama Blue Bloods.

Bridget Moynahan was born Kathryn Bridget Moynahan in Binghamton, New York on April 28, 1971, to Mary Bridget a former schoolteacher, and Edward Bradley Moynahan, a scientist and former administrator at the University of Massachusetts Amherst both of Irish American descent. She has two brothers, Andy and Sean, and has said that, during her childhood, she was a tomboy. At around seven years old, her family moved to Longmeadow, Massachusetts where she attended Longmeadow High School and was captain of the girls’ soccer, basketball, and lacrosse teams.

Upon her graduation from Longmeadow High School in 1989, She had to convince her parents to let her try out modeling and acting as they had planned for her to go to business school. She actively began pursuing a career in modeling having been signed by a modeling agency after accompanying a friend to an audition.

Having appeared in many fashion magazines, including on the covers of Vogue and Glamour magazine, department-store catalogs, and television commercials, she began taking acting classes at the Caymichael Patten Studio in New York.

Though Moynahan made her television debut in a guest appearance in the comedy series Sex and the City in 1999, where she later had a recurring role as Natasha, her feature film debut in the 2000 comedy-drama Coyote Ugly playing the role of Rachel, a bartender/dancer in a wild New York bar is considered Moynahan’s breakthrough. According to her, she had accepted the role because she “thought it was interesting that the whole movie revolved around five women, and her character Racheal was so strong and independent”. The film garnered generally unfavorable critical reviews, but was a box-office success, earning $133 million worldwide.

In 2004, Moynahan starred alongside Will Smith in Alex Proyas I’s science fiction film I-Robot, which is loosely based on Isaac Asimov’s short story collection of the same name, in which psychologist Dr. Susan Calvin is shown. Robot. After its release, I-Robot, received mixed reviews, although critics appreciated Moynahan’s performance. Richmond Times-Dispatch’s Daniel Neman, who disliked the film, concluded that she “becomes a deft performance as Dr. Calvin, the comfortable character”.

In September 2006, Moynahan starred alongside Jay Hernandez, Erika Christensen, Hope Davis, Dorian Missick, and Campbell Scott as Whitney Crane on the ABC television series Six Degrees. The series revolved around six New Yorkers and their respective relationships and bonds with one another, based on the idea of ​​six degrees of separation. When it debuted on September 20, 2006, Six Degrees was seen by nearly 13.3 million viewers with varying levels of reception.

The New York Daily News wrote, “In theory, it’s a fascinating concept for a series and this was written by David Hinckley. In practice, however, Six Degrees doesn’t work at all to attract you.” The series was canceled in May 2007 after just one season.

In 2007, Moynahan starred in film roles such as the thriller Unknown, about a group of people who have been kidnapped and trying to work together to escape their captors. Gray Matters with Heather Graham and Tom Cavanagh.

She was cast as Helen Owen, wife of David Owen (played by veteran actor Tim Robbins) in the Henry Bean Noise comedy-drama. The film was shown in a special presentation at the 2007 Rome Film Festival and released in 2008.

She also starred in several motion pictures such as Serendipity, The Sum of All Fears, The Recruit, Lord of War, Prey, Ramona and Beezus, John Wick, The Journey Home, and John Wick: Chapter 2.

In 2006, Maxim named his number 96 on his annual Hot 100 list.

Moynahan dated and lived with screenwriter Scott Rosenberg from 2001 to 2003. Despite his success in the theatrical world, Brady’s life remained relatively low-key and free from media spotting until his dramatic breakup with NFL star Tom. She dated the New England Patriots quarterback from 2004 through December 14, 2006, her agent confirming her split from People in December 2006, stating that they had “ended their three-year relationship by mutual agreement.”

The news of Moynahan’s pregnancy was first reported a few months after her split from Brady by New York Post columnist Liz Smith. Her agent later confirmed to People magazine on February 18, 2007, that she was pregnant. over three months old and that Brady was the father.

The media got into a frenzy with the news and caught media attention, which Moynahan was not prepared for as Brady was already dating his then-girlfriend, now wife, Brazilian model Gisele Bündchen. She was quoted as saying times about her pregnancy and her child was “stolen” by paparazzi and tabloids for being in public.

On August 22, 2007, she gave birth to their son, John Edward Thomas (Jack) Moynahan. In a July 2008 interview with Harper’s Bazaar, Moynahan discussed her desire as a single mother to raise her son. Despite media reports that Moynahan and Brady had a bitter relationship, it was revealed that the two had been in a civilian relationship since their son was born.

After mentioning in a press release that she was introduced to Garnier Nutritionist while working on a movie and that she liked the feel of her skin, she signed a contract with Garnier in November 2009 to appear in TV and print ads for her July 2010 release Advertise skincare products (Ultra-Lift).

She moved from Pacific Palisades, California to New York City in 2010 when she was cast as ADA Erin Reagan on the drama series Blue Bloods.

She started dating director and producer McG, also known as director Joseph McGinty Nichol, in late 2010, but the relationship was short-lived since she started dating Andrew Frankel in 2013.

On October 17, 2015, to the surprise of fans, Moynahan was largely silent about the relationship she announced on her Instagram. She tied the knot with businessman Andrew Frankel by posting a photo of their wedding in the vineyard with the caption, “Oh, by the way, guess what I just did @johndolanphotog #sohappy #perfection #friends #family #forever”.

The stunning, intimate ceremony took place in the Hamptons with the couple surrounded by family and friends.

Bridget Moynahan Instagram

ABC’s Six Degrees told the stories of six very different New Yorkers who are actually connected in various and unknown ways. The series starred Jay Hernandez, Erika Christensen, Hope Davis, Dorian Missick, Bridget Moynahan, and Campbell Scott, and was co-executive produced by Lost’s J.J. Abrams.

Six Degrees debuted on September 21, 2006 and was pulled from the airwaves after only six episodes due to low ratings. ABC assured fans of the show that the series would return in January. That didn’t happen. In January, ABC Entertainment President Stephen McPhearson said of The Nine and Six Degrees, “those two actually may get back on the air in (primetime).” Not a guarantee for sure.

The one promising point was this: though ABC only ordered 13 episodes, Six Degrees is actually still in production in New York City. The cast and crew reportedly took some time off to creatively retool the series and Josh Charles (who you may remember from Aaron Sorkin’s Sports Night) has been added to the cast.

ABC has just announced that Six Degrees will return to primetime on Friday, March 23rd at 9pm. It’s unknown how long it will remain in that slot but hopefully fans can see the seven unaired episodes.

Now, if the revisions to Six Degrees are successful and the show attracts decent ratings, it’s possible that ABC could give the go-ahead for future episodes and perhaps even a second season. It’s a bit of a long shot but you never know. Stay tuned!

But just as relationships formed online can have their own intense pleasures, so do these fleeting path-crossings manage to trump more conventional having-and-holding partnerships. They lift the characters in “Six Degrees” out of their familiar rounds and suggest that a grander and more precious life is possible.

Image Bridget Moynahan, left, and Hope Davis on ABCs Six Degrees. Credit... Eric Liebowitz/ABC

On tonight’s first episode, Whitney (Ms. Moynahan), a sexy executive, fears that her insouciant British boyfriend is cheating on her. As she tries to catch him in a lie, she also encounters Steven (Mr. Scott), a photographer and recovering drug addict who longs to be reunited with his school-age son. While having a pedicure, she also starts talking to Laura (Ms. Davis), a recent widow with a daughter. Laura’s husband, we learn, was a television reporter who died in Iraq.

Mae, or Claire (Ms. Christensen), comes Laura’s way because she’s looking for baby-sitting work while she’s on the lam. Either the police or, more likely, bad guys are chasing her. She’s good in the role of con girl, giving away neither too much nor too little as she conceals her predicament and half-falls for Carlos (Mr. Hernandez). Damian (Mr. Missick) is a limousine driver with gambling debts; his kindness to his customers coupled with his ruinous lusty passion for betting makes it hard for anyone but his bookie to dislike him. I’m hoping he becomes less angelic as the series goes on.

But the particular stories are not what “Six Degrees” is ultimately about. Instead the show’s forte, for viewers like me who don’t mind piety on television, is its ambience of faith, particularly in the ebullient, Whitmanian idea of “contact” in the city, by which he meant everything from a stranger’s glance to her kiss (and more). “Six Degrees” is, yes, a defunct title; John Guare already wrung out its significance in his great play “Six Degrees of Separation.” Though stuck with the title, Mr. Abrams is still expected to have fun with this show.

The truth is that the characters in this series, unlike the strangers on opposite sides of the planet in the original “six degrees” formulation, have about one degree between them. This is an extremely reverent show. Dare we call that one degree God?
